body.1: Here's a notebook that includes some example uses (either from the command line or in python). It uses nilearn to get a stat map so it should work out of the box. All cells have been cleared, so it's only 4KB or so.
body.2:
Should we extract multiple peaks per cluster, like in SPM?

An idea would be to extract all peaks per cluster (ordered by intensity) but exclude new peaks if they are too close to already included peaks.
body.3:
Hi all, 

Just tossing out a few ideas regarding the output file. Currently the output file contains both peak and cluster information, as shown below:


ClusterID | Peak_Location | Cluster_Mean | Volume | Harvard_Oxford
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
Cluster01 | 60.0_-19.0_46.0 | 7.2740965 | 27324 | 48.91% Postcentral_Gyrus
Cluster02 | -24.0_-31.0_73.0 | -7.2317147 | 11772 | 63.53% Postcentral_Gyrus; 36.24%   Precentral_Gyrus
Cluster03 | -9.0_-58.0_-17.0 | 6.786522 | 5049 | 88.77% No_label
Cluster04 | 51.0_-22.0_19.0 | 6.641388 | 4293 | 39.62% Parietal_Operculum_Cortex;   37.74% Central_Opercular_Cortex
Cluster05 | 24.0_-49.0_-26.0 | -6.504359 | 3618 | 88.06% No_label
Cluster06 | 6.0_-10.0_52.0 | 6.0106235 | 2646 | 63.27%   Juxtapositional_Lobule_Cortex_(formerly_Supplementary_Motor_Cortex)
Cluster07 | 33.0_-7.0_-2.0 | 6.2991576 | 378 | 85.71% Right_Putamen
PeakID | Peak_Location | Peak_Value | Volume | Harvard_Oxford
Peak01 | 60.0_-19.0_46.0 | 7.941345 | 27324 | 44% Postcentral_Gyrus
Peak02 | -24.0_-31.0_73.0 | -7.9414444 | 11772 | 47% Postcentral_Gyrus
Peak03 | -9.0_-58.0_-17.0 | 7.941345 | 5049 | 0% No_label
Peak04 | 51.0_-22.0_19.0 | 7.941345 | 4293 | 55% Parietal_Operculum_Cortex
Peak05 | 24.0_-49.0_-26.0 | -7.9414444 | 3618 | 0% No_label
Peak06 | 6.0_-10.0_52.0 | 7.941345 | 2646 | 53%   Juxtapositional_Lobule_Cortex_(formerly_Supplementary_Motor_Cortex)
Peak07 | 33.0_-7.0_-2.0 | 7.9053116 | 378 | 71% Right_Putamen

You'll notice a second header row with `PeakID`  is followed by the peak information rows. This makes it difficult to use with say, `pandas`, because now the column types will all be set as `object` and won't reflect the actual data type (e.g., `Cluster_Mean` should be `float`). 

So, my first suggestion is to break up these tables into a `peak.csv` and a `cluster.csv` with a way to link the peaks with their clusters across tables (i.e. using a column that matches a peak to its cluster). 

My second suggestion is to break coordinate information into separate x, y, and z columns (i.e. peak_x, peak_y, peak_z) so that these can fit cleanly in a table. 

Let me know what you guys think or what other improvements might be worthwhile. I'm happy to work on this.
body.4: @rmarkello - I'm not really sure what the `setup.py` file implies. But do we want to package the toolbox with `pypi` so that people can download it with a pip command? Do you otherwise know how to put it into a conda framework?
body.5:
@rmarkello, @danjgale, @asidwell - Does anyone of you want to create a nice example jupyter notebook or a script that shows nicely what the toolbox does?

Also, we need a description for this toolbox that appears on the mainpage just below the title. Any suggestions?
body.6: This ended up being a dual pull request addressing #11 but also some fixes for providing multiple atlases. First, I added the option to specify the output directory (if not specified, the output directory defaults to the input path, as per the command line help). Then, the handling of multiple atlases was fixed following the integration of  #8 and #18. The code works nicely with specifying one or more atlases using argparse.
body.7:
Closes #10 and closes #14. The latter because I decided as I was making these changes that it was unreasonable (the atlas API in nilearn is not consistent enough to work for this!).

This moves `atlases` and `templates` into the main module to be bundled with install as "package data." All references to atlases and templates in the primary code have been updated to reflect this move.
body.8:
The `create_output()` function is rather sizeable and aims to do multiple things, including running the cluster analyses, generating the output CSV file, _and_ creating the cluster map images; it would be great to split it up a bit to improve modularity and ease testing and readability! In my mind those could be three functions (at least!), something like:

1. `gen_cluster_df()`, which does most of the work (wrapping the first part of the function)
2. `save_table()`, which outputs the CSV file (and maybe other table formats, like LaTeX, as desired)
3. `save_cluster_images()`, which outputs the cluster map images (allowing more control over image formatting!)

I'm happy to discuss the best mechanism for doing this, but would love to see it chopped up a bit before proceeding too far.
body.9:
Hi all, 

Just made some updates to the docstrings (see #7) – what I mentioned in #13 . Cleaned up whitespace and formatting, as well as improved some definitions for various parameters for clarity's sake.
body.10:
Closes #3.

This probably should have been the first PR I made but better late than never. @miykael and I are currently listed as members of the team for handling reporting of violations, but am happy to consider expanding that (to, at most, 4 individuals) on a case-by-case basis.
body.11:
Right now we're limiting the atlas + template options to the ones that are shipped with the repository (though see #4 for discussion of removing those), but we could also expand this to include any of the atlases / templates that are accessible via the [`nilearn.datasets`](http://nilearn.github.io/modules/reference.html#module-nilearn.datasets) package! If one of those atlases is requested (say, [`atlas_msdl`](http://nilearn.github.io/modules/generated/nilearn.datasets.fetch_atlas_msdl.html#nilearn.datasets.fetch_atlas_msdl)), then the appropriate `nilearn` fetch-style command could be called and the atlas downloaded + used.

I think this would be really worthwhile since `nilearn` is incredibly good about incorporating new atlases quickly after they're released. This may (at least temporarily) resolve the need for a separate repo in #4 (sorry, `corgi`)!
body.12: Initial draft of docstrings of functions. Addresses issue #7
body.13:
- [ ] Ready to merge

Closes #8 (and working on closing #11!)

This PR removes all mention of `sys.argv` and uses the `argparse` module to better handle command line inputs.
body.14: Currently, output files save to the directory of the input stat map. An idea is to have this as the default, but also have the option to specify a new directory should if preferred.
body.15: While I was working on documentation and testing out some functionalities, I had to fix the data file paths because the `atlas` and `templates` directories have been relocated. My solution – only to work in a pinch – was just adding relative paths in the existing code. A longer term and a more stable solution is needed.
body.16: Currently missing a requirements.txt or environment.yml (if we go with conda)
body.17:
User-provided input in `atlas_reader.py` is currently being pulled directly from the command line via calls to `sys.argv`. It would be wonderful to see this handled instead by [`argparse`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#module-argparse), which provides a load of benefits over directly accessing `sys.argv`, including detailed documentation on what inputs **need to** (versus _can_) be provided! 

This would require replacing all the calls to `sys.argv` in `atlas_reader.py` with arguments in an [`argparse.ArgumentParser`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/argparse.html#argumentparser-objects) object. Ideally, some information about what those arguments should look like would also be included! A how-to guide for argparse is available [here](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/argparse.html), for those who are new to it.
body.18:
We need doc-strings! The current functions in `atlas_reader.py` have one-line descriptions of their functionality, if that. I am personally a fan of [`numpy`-style doc-strings](http://numpydoc.readthedocs.io/en/latest/format.html) since they interface so nicely with online documentation (like [Sphinx](http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/)!).

It would be great if someone would be willing to go through the functions and document them with at least (1) a short description, (2) parameters + types, and (3) return values.

I talked to @danjgale about doing this, but if anyone else has thoughts on doc-strings this is the place to discuss!
body.19:
I forgot to add the actual code for installing the package in the test
environment. Also, added some documentation things to make it more
appealing!
body.20:
Closes #1 

This PR moves things around a little bit to create a bare bones Python package setup (i.e., so it is installable with `python setup.py install`). I also added the skeleton for testing and continuous integration with TravisCI! We just need to turn that on.
body.23:
Is there any reason the license is GPL? I'm more a fan of MIT or BSD, especially for these sorts of projects that could very reasonably be incorporated into other projects! 

What are your thoughts about potentially changing it to something more permissive?
body.24: Currently all the work in this repo exists as a single file (`atlas_reader.py`). I think this will eventually become somewhat unwieldy as functionality is added/updated, so I'm planning to work on quickly converting everything into a more standard python package framework. I'll try to whip this up quickly so edits can be made—I'll open a PR soon!

title.5: Create example notebook explaining the toolbox
title.6: Added output directory option and fixed multiple atlas handling
title.13: WIP, ENH: Incorporate argparse for command-line parsing
title.14: Have option to specify output directory
